Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisistion of an Illumina NextSeq 500 to Support Life Science Research at South Dakota State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to South Dakota State University to purchase an Illumina NextSeq500 nucleic acid sequencer and ancillary equipment to support research in the Life Sciences. The purchase of this instrumentation will contribute to the development of learning and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at SDSU as well as researchers in the State of South Dakota and the region. In addition the instrumentation will allow introducing the technology and its applications to students (7th-12th grade) participating in the Annual Eastern South Dakota Science Fair.

The purchase of this equipment will advance research projects in both plant and animal sciences and in cell biology. The sequencer will allow plant scientists to answer fundamental questions in plant development; how plants adapt to and interact within their environment. Genetic scientists will make gains in food crops to ensure a safe, secure food supply. Animal scientists will improve the nutrition of animals that are raised as food sources. Cell biologists will apply the technology to study the basic mechanisms of all living things on a cellular level, laying a foundation of knowledge for scientist worldwide. This knowledge gained with the use of this new equipment will lead to scientific advancements in health, nutrition and disease prevention in plants, animals and humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this award we have stablished the first service sequencing facility in the state of South Dakota. This has facilitated the expansion of the use of DNA sequencing applications across research projects in the state. We have been able to expand the facility with additional support from the South Dakota State University Agricultural Experimental Station and the SD-EPSCOR program. The facility now provides service with three sequencers, up from one in the MRI project, and three robotic systems for sample preparation.

During the award period we have supported over fifty project applications many of them successfully. The projects we have supported ranged from environmental sciences to plant genetics, food safety and biomedical research areas. These projects have yielded several publications in high quality journals.

The award has allowed us to provide different levels of training to over 200 trainees including undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs and faculty. Training activities have included one to one training and group workshops of different length. In some of these workshops, trainees have sequenced, assembled and annotated genomes from new bacterial isolates. We have translated this model of workshops to a new graduate level class where currently students are conducting a RNAseq experiment in plants including writing and submission of a collective manuscript. We have also used this model in two research summer programs for undergraduates.

Additionally, Dr. Gonzalez Hernandez has developed multiple outreach activities targeting middle and high schools students in central eastern South Dakota. The number of students in these activities is over 600.
